Not a long walk at all and you're actually in the best part of Waikiki. The Laylow was just remodeled! Fresh and new!Pool was small but enough for us. The king-size adjustable seating mats made this more appealing and comfortable than the crowded beach. We regret not spending more time at the pool. Morning sun only though.Go to the hotel bar for (pricey, but this Honolulu) cocktails. This is a hip hotel geared for any adult, but it is hip and cool. Don't shy away from the swanky bar. The DJs at the bar Friday & Saturday spun some pretty cool music. Everyone was happy to be there - great vibes. High end shopping is close by on the Rodeo Drive or 5th Avenue of Honolulu. Public transit was very regular. Cheap breakfast $4.95 special a block away across street from Starbucks.All in all I would recommend this hotel to anyone. When I go back, I will fork over $$$ to stay there.

I stayed at the Laylow in late May 2017 and stayed at its next door neighbor, the Hyatt Centric, a few days later after returning from Maui, and let me tell you these are the two coolest new hotels in Waikiki. Both are great hotels for different reasons and both are very welcome additions to a tired Waikiki hotel scene. If you haven’t been to Waikiki lately, you will be amazed by how these two hotels and the all-new International Market Place next door have transformed Kuhio Ave. I actually preferred staying at these hotels over the beachfront resorts because, with the exception of Halekulani, the beachfront resorts are anything but chill plus I never sit on the beach anyway. Also worth noting that the Laylow and Hyatt Centric are not just next door neighbors but they seem to have the exact same target market, and it was clear that neither hotel wanted to be outdone by its neighbor (e.g., live music at the bar most nights, gift baskets upon arrival, welcome drinks, etc.), all of which benefit the hotel guests. The Laylow marks Marriott's return to the Waikiki hotel scene after the disastrous Waikiki Edition. It was formerly the 3-star Aqua Waikiki Wave and was extensively renovated and reflagged as a member of The Autograph Collection (as a side note, which, The Autograph Collection adds even more confusion to Marriott's already confusing hotel brands (for instance, in Los Angeles, the hierarchy of Ritz Carlton to JW Marriott to Renaissance to Courtyard to Residence Inn is clear as day as you drive down Olympic Blvd, yet in Phoenix, the Camelback Inn, arguably the most iconic Marriott of all, is branded as a JW Marriott and is much nicer than the Ritz Carlton, which was just re-branded as an Autograph Collection). Apparently the Autograph Collection designation is more about the uniqueness of the hotel than its level of luxury. It's also worth noting that the Laylow's sister hotel in Hawaii is the iconic Mauna Kea on the big island, which, along with the Kahala Hilton, was considered among the very finest hotels in the world. Anyway, who could have ever imagined that the Mauna Kea might one day not only end up in the same sentence as the former Aqua Waikiki Wave but also end up as its sister hotel?!?! But I digress...so let's get back to my Laylow visit:Pros:• An long exterior escalator transports you from the unassuming exterior of the hotel to an amazing open air lobby and pool area, which feels you have entered another world...an urban escape that somehow feels a million miles away from the madness of Waikiki below. Possibly the coolest lobby in Waikiki, especially because it’s so unexpected (think 10 Downing Street).• All rooms have private balconies. I realized what a big deal this was when I stayed at the Hyatt Centric the following week, where none of the rooms have balconies or even windows that open• Rooms seemed well-insulated except that the doors slam shut. Need to add a soft-close mechanism• Beds, pillows and linens are excellent• Location is perfect, especially with the recent opening of The Street social house, a high-end food court/social house on the ground floor (facing Kuhio) of the all-new International Market Place. • Room service (but hours are limited unlike at the Hyatt Centric next door, which has 24 hour room service)• Great restaurant and bar with live music on the terrace many nights• Awesome gift basket with many treats including my new favorite candy, Hi-Chew• Pool is stunningCons:• After checking in, I walked to the elevators and was suddenly reminded that this was an older hotel. It feels like the owners spent 80% of their renovation budget on the amazing lobby and pool, and the rest of the hotel (e.g., the hallways and, to a certain extent, the rooms) were an afterthought• The hotel and especially the rooms are a mix of luxury and kitsch. The lighting in the rooms is terrible, as they opted for these tacky outdated retro lamps with incandescent bulbs and no dimmers, which means you could choose between having the room as bright as a Target store inside or pitch black. Other furnishings include a futon sofa, which was fine, and a tacky lounge chair which was not at all comfortable. The designers should have opted for consistent luxury and quality instead of mixing in so much kitsch. Speaking of which, the Hawaiian dolls at the front desk in the lobby must go!• The bathroom was the same story. The plumbing hardware, vanity and lighted round wall mirror above the sink were of excellent quality; the fake wood-paneled shower was tacky and felt out of place. If they wanted a retro look, marble always works. There was also a very cheap small non-lighted vanity mirror attached to the wall which seemed like an afterthought. Overall, it felt a little bit like some corners were cut with finishes in order to meet a construction deadline, and hopefully this will change over time. The guest rooms themselves are actually better at Hyatt Centric except for the lack of balconies (I also had a suite at the Hyatt Centric so I'm not sure how the standard guest rooms compare).• Staff tried to be helpful and friendly but it was clear they were still learning. By comparison, the staff at Hyatt Centric was excellent and on it. In fairness to The Laylow, the hotel had literally just opened a few days earlier.• No ice machines in hallways, which means you have to call for ice every time you want it. This is a big deal to me. I loved how Hyatt Centric not only had ice machines but also water stations to refill water.• Another big deal to me was that room service is not 24 hours at the Laylow. Hyatt Centric has 24 hour room service.• Alarm clock was difficult to set and came with no instructions. I had to finally look up the owner’s manual online. It was not at all intuitive.Despite the cons listed above, I am still giving the Laylow a 5 rating because it’s such a unique and welcome addition to the Waikiki hotel scene. If you are looking for a chill spot to lay low and escape the madness of Waikiki, this is definitely it.If you are considering Laylow vs Hyatt Centric, it’s a really tough call and you really can't go wrong with either one. For me, I give the edge to Laylow because of the balconies. As much as I loved the Hyatt Centric, I’m not sure I would stay there again because of the lack of balconies or even windows that open, which seems crazy in Hawaii.

I've stayed at several hotels in Waikiki including the Hilton Hawaiian Village, Marriott and Westin Surfrider. I decided to try this newly renovated hotel as it is a Marriott property. It is an older hotel that has been totally renovated and they did a nice job. It has a clean Hawaiian vibe. It was quiet and a nice break away from the crowded feeling of Waikiki. So, if you are looking for a quality place to relax in the heart of the shopping and restaurants, it's great. If you are looking for a beachfront experience this is not it. It's a solid 2 and a half blocks to the sand of Waikiki beach. If you are looking for an expansive pool to take in the sun, this is not it. The pool is nice but very small and tucked between the high rise buildings so it only is in the sun for a few hours mid-day. Pool chairs are very limited due to space. It's truly a place to "lay low" and relax close to, but away from, all the hustle and bustle of Waikiki.

This is a fun, centrally located, relaxed hotel that offers good value. It has s great roof top bar and restaurant that often offers live music to accompany signature cocktails, great service and pretty good food. The rooms are good sized and well appointed with small balconies. The TV has Netflix which our kids really enjoyed. There is a small but nice pool with plenty of sunbeds and an adjacent gym. We used the valet parking which was convenient. We also dined at the restaurant and enjoyed the food. We thought that this hotel offered great value and we lived it's central location right in the middle of a vibrant part of Waikiki / next door to a huge shopping centre and a block from the beach.

I would recommend The Laylow to anyone traveling to Oahu, period! The hotel property is beautifully laid out from the pool area, to the restaurant, and of course all the way to the rooms including a nice basket of gifts upon arrival! This Hotel is the epitomizes 'aloha'.. The valet, front desk, housekeeping team, wait and bartending staff was phenomenal. I have to give credit to the management team as well. They go above and beyond for the guest. Dawn and Andrea were managers that I interacted with and they were awesome! Proximity to food, shopping and of course the beach! I was very pleased and look forward to booking a stay with my family this coming winter! Thanks again and big shout out to ALL of the staff for making my 26 day work assignment feel like a vacation! Mahalo!

We stayed in a cabana room right off pool . No control over other rude guest sitting in our area out our door in WET bathing suits. No children control with water pistols etc. They make up empty rooms first as a result ours was still unmade after we'd been out for 8 hours and just wanted to come back and rest.
user_name:
Larry D
pittsburg calif, United States

review_body: We enjoyed a great stay at the Laylow which is a Marriott property, part of the Autograph Collection. Fortunately someone clued us into the Marriott connection, as we are Marriott loyalists. Outstanding staff, such as manager Andrea Novak who showed us a few rooms before we made a reservation to be sure that we would like our room. We need drapes that block the sunlight in the morning so that we can sleep past 7 a.m. Excellent location, just a few blocks from the beach. Lively social scene on the terrace with a DJ most nights. MiniFridge in room is convenient.

We are Gold Marriott members and were upgraded to corner suite. We were ok with no view. Traveling with 2 daughters, the hotel offered to make the couch into bed and same for corner alcove "couch". 5 hours later we return and they hadn't been to room. Eventually a man came who didn't know how you needed a top sheet and pillows. Next day we leave for day around Oahu. We return at 5;40 and our room hasn't been serviced. No towels, no beds made, etc. We call and cleaning staff has left for day. We were told they had a lot of check ins. It's a hotel! When they sent someone up, he didn't know how to make up a room and wasn't happy about having to do it. In the 3 nights we were there they never cleaned the shower. It clogged and I removed metal cover to clean drain. The sand stayed in the far corner of the back side of the shower. We had to call for towels and shampoo, soap. The cleaning cart stayed in our hotel floor hallway all day and night but it only had sheets. We also had difficulty getting help from concierge. Executive floor coffee machine had powered milk and they need to tell kids not to expect donuts after 8:00am BC they're gone and some days the donuts are actually muffins. Everytime we went past the front desk there were customers waiting in line with 1-2 staff Manning the hotel desk. I get this hotel just opened in March, but their operations are awful. My husband and I have been traveling for work/holiday for over 30 years. This was one of the worst ever. The décor is cheap looking and the bed was not comfortable. The flat screen TV was very nice and big.

While I was out in Honolulu for business, I stopped by the Laylow to see if it would be a good fit for a longer stay later in the year. The front office manager could not have been more accommodating in showing me around the hotel and the different room options. As fate would have it, I needed to extend my current stay in Honolulu and I jumped at the chance to stay the weekend at the Laylow. The rooms are wonderfully appointed and the decor is fabulous: mid-century modern at its finest! I highly recommend the larger suite. It's well thought out with everything you might need for your stay. While I didn't have the opportunity to enjoy the pool, it certainly looks inviting. But I did get the chance to enjoy the cocktail bar and restaurant. The bar has the best cocktails I've had on the island and the dinner was delicious. Even a slight glitch in the server coverage for my table was quickly resolved and the Laylow treated me to a drink in return. So if you're looking for a stylish hotel with great service, good food, fabulous cocktails, a friendly staff, and a location right in the heart of Waikiki, look no further than the Laylow!

This is a beautiful hotel very close to Waikiki beach. It is decorated in a retro beach theme. The wallpaper in our room is cool pink and blue palm leaves. The staff is super friendly and helpful. It is fun being right next to the new International Market where they have a nightly free hula show! There is an ABC store right next door where we get snacks and essentials, as well as a yummy little taco stand across the street. They have a great infinity pool with lounge chairs in the water and covered cabanas at one end. Overall an awesome hotel that isn't too pricey. I would definitely recommend this hotel to friends and family that visit!

My fiance and I stayed here for 3 nights in May, about 2 months after the Laylow opened. We are so glad we took a chance making a reservation when it hadn't even opened yet! (In fact, I think the hotel name changed between the time we made the reservation and the grand opening) It was our second time in Waikiki; the first time we had stayed in a more expensive hotel (The Modern), but we ended up preferring the Laylow. The vibe is wonderful, with a modern, stylish take on mid-century Hawaiiana. We had great service at the bar/restaurant, where we enjoyed live music every night. We even got upgraded to a junior suite (thanks to my fiance's Marriott status). The only downsides were the ongoing construction next door that woke us up by 7am every day, and the small pool area with limited sun. The construction won't last forever and we can live with a less-than-perfect pool, so we would certainly stay at the Laylow the next time we find ourselves in Waikiki!

This hotel has the best location, short walk to the beach,next door to Market place and a walk through it would take you on the main strip, close to all shops and restaurants but away from all the hussel and bussel. We had breakfast included which I highly recommend (order of a menu). The staff were very friendly and helpful. The hotel has just been renovated and everything is new and very clean.This is apsolutely where I would stay again when I return to Waikik

From the moment you step onto the escalator going up to the lobby you are transported to a hip, beautiful, fun oasis in the middle of Waikiki. It is decorated with a mid century modern Hawaiian vibe. The pool is off the lobby hidden behind an architecturally pleasing wooden screen and plants. The service was impeccable when I was there even though the hotel had only been open a few weeks before. The room was large and had plenty of space to move around in. The bathroom was a bit small but they did the best they could with the space they had. The bed was VERY comfortable. I loved the welcome basket in my room. I stayed in an executive room and loved having unlimited access to filtered water (pack your Swell bottle) and the snacks were good too. Each morning they brought in fresh pastries and each evening they brought in fun snacks and cookies. The room was clean, nice and new which is so unusual to find in Waikiki. It was decorated very well. The wallpaper was a fun Hawaiian print. The desk is negligible but I worked on my laptop on the balcony instead of the desk. The high speed wifi is great! And you can log into your Netflix and Hulu accounts on the TV.I didn't mind being a couple of blocks away from the beach because it was so nice. You are right next to International Marketplace which has good restaurants but the shopping isn't worth it. There isn't anything there that you can't already get on the mainland. The restaurants at IMP are really good and they have a Japanese market that makes fresh musubi. You MUST go to StripSteak and get the tasting menu. Best meal on the whole island.

We stayed 2 nights not expecting a resort atmosphere as we were sightseeing and wanted close proximity to restaurants and shops. The Laylow provided that nicely. The style and layout of the hotel and public spaces were very appealing. The front desk staff was friendly and our rooms were clean and fresh. We reserved here also for the fact that it offered 2 king size beds in the double rooms. A few suggestions would be, an outside shower by the pool, mini coffee maker in the room (the coffee bar is pricey) and hooks in the bathroom to hang a robe or towel besides the towel bar on the shower door. Otherwise this was a great option for those who are on the go and want accessibility to everything. We were happy here!
user_name:
Allison E
Fullerton, California, United States

review_body: This hotel is located a short walk to Waikiki Beach and right next to the International Marketplace. It is a new hotel and the fit out is a lovely island vibe. The downside was that at night it was a bit noisy and I was on the 8th floor - maybe request a higher floor. I think noise is generally an issue in most Waikiki hotels. The positive side is that the bar and restaurant were fantastic with friendly and attentive staff that made you feel at home.

I have platinum status with Marriott as a result of staying over 100 nights per calendar year with Marriott at its various brands. Platinum status is supposed to mean something, but not at The Laylow.Management is cheating elites by breaking the spirit of Marriott's elite program rules. The complimentary breakfast is a joke. In fact, pretty much anyone can get access to the "lounge" for breakfast. The lounge isn't actually a lounge. It's just countertops and cabinets in a hallway on the "executive level" floor. The breakfast itself is pathetic -- by far the worst of any Marriott hotel. In fact, a no-frills Holiday Inn Express or even the Marriott brand Fairfield Inn offers a better breakfast. At The Laylow, all you get is free coffee and doughnuts. That's it. No yogurt. No oatmeal. No eggs. Nothing even remotely healthy. The hotel doesn't even provide coupons for a discount if one wants breakfast off the menu in the lobby-level restaurant. I skipped the restaurant as the prices were ridiculously expensive: $16 for a yogurt parfait and $8 for cereal. A cappuccino was $5, which is more expensive than Starbucks. Instead, I went to the Moana Westin and had breakfast, including coffee, juice and tip/tax, on their porch facing the beach for $23. "Executive level" rooms are also supposed to receive "complimentary non-alcoholic beverages." The only beverages were coffee, water and juice. The juice was gone by early morning. At every other Marriott hotel, this would include soda pop.The Laylow also charges a resort fee of $25 per day -- they call it an "amenity fee." I would have less objection to the fee if the hotel was actually a resort on the beach. It isn't. It's a city hotel located on a very busy street a couple blocks from Waikiki Beach. There are zero resort amenities. The rooftop pool is nice, but it's very small even by city hotel standards. Also, the pool doesn't get much sunshine because of neighboring buildings.Outside of these complaints, the recently opened and renovated hotel is a gorgeous example of mid-century modern architecture. I liked the design. It's just too bad that the management has decided to penny pinch.

We went on a family vacation with our daughters, sons-in-law and grandbabies. We had three rooms at the hotel. We loved the location, and the public spaces of the hotel itself were nice. We were disappointed in the fact that after spending four nights in that hotel, our room was cleaned once, and our daughters' and sons-in-laws rooms were not cleaned at all, other than having the beds made. Even worse, they didn't empty the trash, didn't even wipe down the counters in the bathrooms and didn't take any dirty glassware or dishes away. Even though this is a newer hotel, opened in March 2017, the beds are well-worn and uncomfortable. When we asked the front desk about cleaning the rooms, several times, they apologized and said it shouldn't happen. Mind you, we had three rooms on three different floors, so the problem is throughout the hotel. The confusing and finicky elevators and room keys left people stuck in the elevators trying to figure out how the heck to get up to their rooms. The pool area was fine. Unlike some reviews we read, we did not have trouble finding a place to sit out by the pool. However, they have many large umbrella stands with no umbrellas and when we asked for one, they said they didn't have any as the ones they had were a safety hazard and they have not gotten new ones yet. Also, it would have been nice to have servers out by the pool area instead of having to go into the bar to order food or drinks poolside, even they did have a pile of pool menus to look at so you could go order. I cannot recommend this hotel to anyone as I don't like spending that kind of money and not ever even seeing someone actually cleaning the rooms or vacuuming or taking the trash away.

Great hotel, staff was excellent. Stayed on the 16th floor which had small club like amenities. Decor of the room was very retro. Best oatmeal ever, roof top bar and restaurant was really cool. We would come back...

This hotel is conveniently located off one of the three main streets in Waikiki. Beach is a ten minutes walk and you can cut through the International Market Place which is just few steps away. There are plenty of stores, restaurants around it (the International Market Place itself is a shopping center, third floor offers a variety of restaurants and The Street on the ground level has different food stands and plenty of sitting room). The hotel bar has a great vibe, good happy hour, and it is a "scene" especially on weekends + they have live entertainment nightly which is a nice perk. The room was nice and spacious (we had a deluxe with 2 kings) and kept very clean and tidy. There was a welcome basket with flip flops and Hawaiian goodies waiting for us in the room which is a great touch. Staff is nice and friendly. Plenty of bus lines you can catch just a few steps away if you would like to explore Honolulu a bit (they take exact change only so have your $2.50 ready). The only con is that the pool/pool area is a bit small and it gets busy on weekends.

If you are wanting to be in the center of everything that is great about Waikiki, The Laylow Autograph Collection is the perfect choice! This Hotel has everything you could want to make a vacation perfect. Less than a 5 minute walk to the famous Waikiki Beach, multiple shops and restaurants, you can't go wrong. The staff are very attentive and always ready to serve their guests.Quick Tip for this location: If you can handle picking up a shuttle or cab at the airport, you can avoid the daily $35.00 valet charge, You can go right next door to the International Market to rent a car to tour the island or take the very regular bus system to get almost anywhere on the island (we rented a car for my job, but I would use my own advice otherwise).Business travelers will love the amenities in the facility, but unfortunately there is not a business center at this location and a very limited space to set up a desktop in the rooms. Regardless, the positives far outweigh the limited business issues. Great restaurant/bar, pool and workout facility.

While others have written of issues, I have to say that I did not experience them. No issues with check-in, elevators, room, load music, Internet access or upper floor amenities (free coffee, water and breakfast pastries is more than I have had at other Autograph Collection properties, so The Laylow exceeded expectations). A plus was the outside bar and food. While not cheap (but in-line with typical Waikiki hotels), the drinks were scratch made and the food was of high quality in a nice setting with music. Next door access to the new International marketplace was a big plus. Will return !

We decided to stay at the Laylow because it was one of what seemed like very few hotels that had rooms with 2 king beds. Most hotels that were on the beach had options for either a single king or 2 double beds. We really wanted to stay at the beach, but a single double bed for our two kids was a non-starter.The hotel is newly remodeled, and everything has a neat, clean look. The pool area was very well done, with a wood deck and wide, comfortable lounge chairs. There are also lounge chairs in the pool. This is a big difference from what we saw at the beach properties, where it seemed like the seating was arranged to cram as many people as possible into a small area. Another nice touch is that they have music playing at a volume level that is not too loud but loud enough to drown out traffic noise from the surrounding streets.The location of the hotel is excellent, with a lot of restaurants and shopping within a short walk. The beach is a short two block walk - maybe 10 minutes. If you really want a chair at the beach you can walk down and rent a pair with umbrella for about $50. The beach is very crowded, and we only went to the beach we could walk to one day.For breakfast we ate at the hotel since we had a package that included breakfast. It was always very good all around - service, quality, etc. There is no Marriot executive lounge, but on the 16th floor there is a nice coffee machine and some fruit and pastries. The kinds of executive lounge service seems to vary somewhat among the Marriot properties. This could be improved, but for us on this trip it was not a big deal since we ate every day in the restaurant. One thing to note is that there is no self parking at the hotel. Space / real estate around the hotel is really tight. The valet service is good, but one thing we learned is that it was easier to grab your car on the street when the valet was bringing it around instead of letting them pull up right to the valet stand. If you don't do this you have to exit through the alley to one side of the hotel. When we were there it was a bit tight as some construction was going on. At times the valet gets really busy, so if it is one of those times you might have to wait a bit for your car.The internet service always worked quite well everywhere in the hotel, including the fitness room.All in all this hotel exceeded my expectations.

Can't say enough about this property! Truly amazing! Loved how everything was right on theme from the concept, to the decor to the decorative straws in your drinks! So, I've been in the hospitality industry for 17 years so sometimes I get disappointed with hotel stays but let me tell you the Laylow Waikiki is hands down one of the best hotel experiences I've ever had. It's trendy but welcoming. All the staff are very friendly and helpful. Shout out to Carrie Chun, one of the food and beverage managers, Sheila and Summer at the front desk and Richard at Concierge. They really made a lasting impression on my stay in terms of exceptional service but also went out of their way to recommend authentic experiences around Waikiki. I'll definitely be back! Such a fantastic location, design, very comfortable and beautiful! Must stay property in Waikiki, recommend mostly for adult travelers but there still was a lot of children. We travelled with a baby and they were very accommodating!! Thank you for everything Laylow Waikiki!!

From the staff at check in to the checkout, this is the BEST hotel I have stayed at in Waikiki.Look, bottom line, I have status at all the major hotel brands, and almost 6 million miles flown. I'm not not new to the travel scene. This stay was a "one off", and I am so glad I stayed here. I cannot described my satisfaction with this property.Thank you, Laylow

Last year we stayed at the Marriott Courtyard in HNL and I wrote an unflattering review, so this time we decided to try Marriott's "Autograph Collection", and were again disappointed. Real estate is expensive here, so that probably accounts for the small rooms. We stayed in the executive level on the top floor, in one of the 4 largest rooms they have, and it was average. It was a standard smallish hotel room with an extra 5 feet width added on, in which they put a small table and seating area. I kept bumping my head on the light over the table getting in and out of the chairs, and I'm short. The bathroom was 5 ft by 5 ft, plus a shower. The room size was adequate for us, but I expected more. We could see a sliver of the ocean between the buildings. The room looked new, however, and was very clean.Breakfast was a small counter opposite the elevator, with a coffee machine, filtered water, orange juice, apples and oranges, and about 15 donuts. During the day, the donuts became a puffed type snack. The creamer on the coffee machine was not working during the 4 days of our stay, even though I let them know. The small front desk does not have change, and we were referred to the bar area, but after waiting a few minutes for the bar tender, I just left - not worth the hassle.I noticed that many of the five star reviews are written by first timers, so I question whether they are real reviews.The hotel is average, maybe ok for the Waikiki area. I'm not impressed with Marriott's "Autograph Collection".

We booked this hotel before it opened, so were thrilled when positive reviews started coming in! We stayed 8 nights, were on the 8th floor on the Dukes Lane side of the building. There was construction next door, but when we closed our balcony door there was no disturbance. Sheila, Summer, Hoku and Victoria (hope all the names are correct) were all lovely, helpful and relatable at reception, as were Frank, Kai, Chris and Kyle at the valet. Beds were soooo comfy, breakfast in the cafe was lovely, and at a leisurely pace (fine for us!) A couple of minor inconsistencies with housekeeping (one day dirty towels removed, and not replaced, another day toilet paper not replenished), had a quick chat with reception and no problems after that (this is not a big 'problem' for me, we're all human after all!). Parked a car for two nights, was aware of the fee. Pool is lovely and quaint. I like the availability of sunblock and fresh iced water poolside. Loved the decor, welcome baskets and service! Dreaming of returning ASAP from New Zealand!

This is a perfect hotel for any type of get away! Next to the newly renovated International Market Place, high end shopping and upscale dining. Walk through the International Market Place and you will find yourself at Waikiki beach. Enjoy a cocktail under the Banyon tree beach bar at the Moana Surfrider or a cup of joe at Honolulu coffee. The hotel has a wonderful ambience the blends old time Hawaiian culture with a modern flair. We will stay here again!!

I had such a great experience here. Hoku took care of us so well. She carefully explained everything to us and answered all of our questions. The room was also very lovely. Beautiful bathroom. Such a lovely design. The restaurant in the hotel, Hideout, was delicious as well. They serve amazing food and good drinks as well. 10/10 will come again.

The Laylow hotel was AMAZING!! Great customer service,friendly staff and the Suite was so spacious!The location of the hotel is awesome.. It's located right next to the NEW International Market Place. Lots ofplaces to eat and shop. Its a good getaway stay on Kuhio Ave. I can't wait to book another stay!

This hotel is amazing! We stayed a week! Service Is superb! The hide out restaurant is wonderful, we ate most of our meals there! Staff could not have been friendlier, and effective!!! I hope to go again.

Summary:There is a basic core of service and competence a hotel must have before it can try to be trendy, unique or different... or Autograph. The Laylow fails in the basic core. Marriott should be embarrassed to associate with such core unprofessionalism and should take immediate steps to use its vast resources (now with Starwood) to bring some competence to the Laylow. On my recent stay as shown below, I was not given room type booked. When I called the front desk about this they said there was a glitch in the Marriott reservation system so I urge everyone to document the type of room they book and want. Random details:Elevator: no key needed, everyone can walk up to any floor (including the Executive Levels)Only 2 elevators = long waitsMy initial room key didn’t work, had to call down for a functional onePool doesn't appear to get any sun as it's surrounded by a parking structure or a tall building on each sideE Komo Mai Amenity box is nice, fun branded flip flops but does not make up for the $25/day resort fee, excuse me, 'destination fee'Nothing in gift shop has price tags; nice stuff but how do they expect to sell anything without price tags or signs listing prices?Great bed, a little harder than a Westin Heavenly bed but overall great comfort and sleepBath amenities great (no parabens, etc.)Entrance to restaurant is awkward, not clear how to get there so most people walk between 2 plants. No signage. No DnD sign in room Left bedside lamp non-functionalEntrance to restaurant is awkward, not clear how to get there so most people walk between 2 plants. No signage. Hotel does not appear to do much more than credit points to Marriott Rewards, upgrades are unlikely and perks are almost non-existent (no breakfast, no lounge, etc.)

Thank you Hokulani (at the front desk) for assisting us when we asked for help or needed extra room supplies. The front desk staff was really friendly and the restaurant had really good food! The waitress with the strong Irish accent was also really nice!

Had an amazing stay here! Thanks Hoku for providing us with excellent and fast customer service. Loved the room too!! The restaurant inside called Hideout is a definite must try! Yummy and super filling! Will definitely come back again!

The staff was wonderful from the time we arrived. We arrived an hour before check in and they gladly checked out bags since everyone was checking out at once. We were past check-in before housekeeping was able to get our room available but Victoria was very professional and took very good care of us. Once in room we were pleasantly surprised to see a welcome basket with assorted snacks, drinks and flip flops, very nice touch. Our view from our double balconies were incredible, being able to sit on the balcony and see the beach was awesome. The hotel has a bar that is very chic and the swimming pool has lounge chairs that actual sit in the water.....fabulous.

My wife and I spent 4 nights here. First and foremost, the staff in the bar and restaurant were great! Staff involved around the front desk and rooms were ok at best. Being hoteliers ourselves for over 15 years we know what it takes to provide great service and they're just not there (yet). First night we arrived late, air conditioner made a incredibly loud bang every time it came on and off. Hardly slept that first night. Reported it to the desk they told us they'd look into it. It took me two follow up request u till later that next day they informed us they'll move us. They told us to pack up our stuff and they'll move it once the room was ready. We went out for about three ours and came back. Got the new room keys but no luggage. "They forgot". I had to go to the desk 2 more times until 40 min later our bags were finally delivered... disappointing! When I spoke to the Front office mgr about the first night she told me that she'll take the destination fee off which equates to about 100$ for our stay. The right thing would've been to take the first night off completely! I'm a Marriott platinum elite member so usually get breakfast at Marriott hotels. This hotel also states they have a continental breakfast but it's really just a doughnut and a coffee machine. Don't expect much here. Valet is also a cluster. I called down 30 minutes before our car pick up but when we got down there they didn't even get the vehicle yet! At one point there was a long line up at the front desk so I asked the concierge if he could call up my vehicle and the response was " You want me to call up your car?" Just not a real service attitude. That being said, Daniel at breakfast was great and Jeffrey at the bar was also awesome. We're moving in the morning to the Royal Hawaiian and hope for better hotel service. The rooms are great and new and hopefully as this hotel matures the service gets better but we leave as unsatisfied guests. Maybe as hoteliers we're to picky with expectations but if you pay good money for a service you'd expect it to be good!

The reviews you will find here all accurately talk about the Laylow. You should really think about what is important to you before you stay here.Here is my perspective based on our stay. Note, we are platinum elite members.Club Level - if you are booking this for the "executive" level or are an elite expecting normal Marriott benefits, do not book here if this is really important. It's a joke quite seriously. Basically anyone can access the 15th and 16th floors to get the "benefits" and there are single serving coffee machines that take a couple minutes to make so the line backs up quite quickly. The food or snacks can only be described as minimal. We basically never used this even though we had access.Basic Hotel Amenities - you will not be getting basics like a coffee maker or ice machines. Yes, they do give you a welcome basket which is a nice touch, but honestly I would prefer the basics. There are also only two elevators and they are slow. Don't be in a super hurry. The rooms are not super huge, but the beds were comfy and we couldn't hear our neighbors above, below or on the sides so that is always a plus. Pool is small and crowded.Elite Member benefits - don't expect anything. In face, when we asked about any upgrades the front desk person tried to tell us we got upgraded when it was the room we had reserved already. Then they gave us a room that was right next to the elevator. Luckily Rachel helped us out when we told her we wanted another room. She agreed that we'd be hearing the elevators often. She was great by the way. I already mentioned that there is no club room. We come to Hawaii frequently and had some discussions about whether to stay at another hotel where we would get access to a real club room and upgrades. It is a choice point. While almost every Marriott that does not have a club room will have elites free breakfast, do not expect this here even though there is a hotel restaurant. I don't think they are trying to attract business travelers to be honest.Location - this saves the place. It is located next to the newly renovated International Marketplace so it is super convenient to shops and restaurants all within walking distance. You are off Kuhio which has improved with all the recent development, but some aspects of old ghetto Kuhio are still there. You are also not super close to the beach. For me when you see the beaches, it is when you start to feel the Aloha feeling. But it is only about a block away. There is also really not a good view. Yes, you can see Diamond Head between buildings and you can sort of get an ocean view between buildings. Staff - very friendly and very good. Some folks mentioned the backup that can happen in the tiny little check in area, but the wait time was never that bad.Autograph Brand - if you are choosing this because of the Autograph brand of Marriott, be warned this one is more boutique and small then some of the luxury Autographs we have stayed in previously and we have stayed in quite a few.Décor - the hotel is nicely designed and the noise between rooms was not bad. There is a hip mid-century vibe to the design. The place is pretty new but there are signs of being worn down already. I am sure these rooms take a beating.Weekend Parties - we did not realize that there are weekend DJs blasting music. The noise did not bother us, but we did give pause to some of the people it attracts. It definitely changes the vibe while that is going on and the lobby area gets packed.Okay, so after all that. We did enjoy our stay and hope as the manager has responded on many of the reviews that noted improvements are under consideration. We are willing to give this place another shot when we return in July so we will see what is "talk" and what is real.

If your idea of Laying Low during a vacation means getting nickeled and dimed, having limited access to the hotel's amenities, and having to deal with an onslaught of blaring party music and drunks your entire stay - then by all means check this place out. If you would rather have good service and rest then you might want to check out another property.The "cons" with this property: you get nickeled and dimed for everything, we had limited access to the hotel's amenities, and the elevators are SLOW. We only booked this property because we had a free night with our Marriott rewards and the Military/Kama'aina rate for follow-on nights was decent. However, after you tack on the hotel taxes, the "resort" fee, and daily parking at $35 a day you are looking at $100 a day in additional fees on top of your room rate. The room lacked staples that you normally get in any room such as in-room coffee and tea. If you are like me and appreciate a cup of coffee or tea in the morning before you shower, forget it. There is no in-room coffee maker. They offer a "coffee bar" in the lobby but the coffee isn't free. It had prices higher than Starbucks and believe me - Starbucks this place is not. I ordered a medium coffee only to be told that they were out of medium cups and could only do small or large. The small was tiny so I opted for the large and was still charged the large price, even though she could have made the medium size serving and just put it in a large cup. Before our stay I called the hotel to ask if they provided a shuttle to the airport. I was told that they offered a shuttle to the airport but not from the airport. Since we only needed transportation to the airport this was perfect. The day of our flight I inquired on the shuttle times only to be notified that the shuttle costs $18 a person. This is highway robbery and information that could have been offered when I inquired about it earlier. We called TheCab instead and ordered a van for a total of $35 for our entire party which was literally less than half the cost of what the hotel shuttle would have been. Lastly, the hotel's restaurant and bar/coffee bar were booked for private parties almost our entire stay. We were able to eat at the restaurant for dinner the night we checked in, but it was closed pretty much the rest of the time. We ended up having to take our business elsewhere. To make matters worse, the private parties had DJ's spinning music the entire time that was so loud, you literally couldn't even communicate with the front desk staff because you could not hear each other over the loud music. Since you have to pass right by the bar to get to the elevators or to the pool you got assaulted every time you passed by. The music was so loud Saturday night that the thumping and bumping could be heard all the way from our room on the 9th floor of the hotel well past 10pm when we were trying to get to bed. Not to mention there were drunk people lingering all over the hotel. It seemed every time we got onto the elevator there was a drunk person about to be sick. There was one particularly precarious elevator ride with a woman who could barely walk and was about to throw up at any moment - I didn't think we were going to make it but she got off on a lower floor than us without being sick in the elevator. We were trying to use the pool one evening and there was a drunk guy passed out cold in a chair by the pool holding a huge bottle of alcohol in a paper bag. We didn't see a hotel security person our entire stay so my guess is this hotel doesn't have any. I attempted to complain about the noise and limited access to amenities to the front desk but got a half-hearted "there isn't really anything I can do about it" attitude.Overall, the hotel itself is well designed with a modern Hawaiian feel and is really pretty. It is centrally located nearby to the new International Marketplace and a short walk to Kalakaua and the Royal Hawaiian Shopping Center so there is plenty to do and places to eat within walking distance. Outside of the modern upgrades to modernize the look and feel of this hotel, there is no mistaking that it is an old hotel that they upgraded. The hotel only has 2 elevators and they are SLOW. We spent a lot of time waiting on an elevator during our stay which is irritating. The hotel pool area is very small with no hot tub and given that Waikiki beach is literally 1 block south of the hotel, surprisingly the pool was packed during the day time. There was not a seat to be had during the day, but after 6pm at night it is a ghost town. The pool is open until 11pm which is the latest I have seen pools and is great for those who prefer to avoid the sun's dangerous rays. We didn't use it but the fitness center seemed to be pretty nice and rarely used since it was empty every time we went by. It even offered fruit infused ice water, fresh fruit, and towels. When we were able to use the hotel's restaurant and bar, we were not impressed. Despite it's very modern and relaxed feel, the place was a zoo on the Friday night we ate there. The service was terrible beyond words and the food and drinks were mediocre as best for outrageous prices. It took over 20 minutes for our drinks to come to the table because we were told no clean glasses were available but yet tables around us who came in after us got their drinks before us. Drinks from the bar average about $15 and are fairly small. Their cocktail list is limited and left a lot of be desired. For similar prices you can get much better drinks and a meal elsewhere. The one night we were able to use the bar we received less than stellar service. We were at the pool and walked over to get drinks. When they learned we were at the pool we were immediately treated like second-class citizens. We were made to wait for a certain bartender, who when she finally came and took our order, ended up refilling and taking new drink orders for all her customers at the bar before she started to make our drinks. Then after they were made she discovered she didn't put them into the right glasses, so I had to wait even longer for her to remake the drinks in the pool glasses. All in all, I waited almost 20 minutes just for two drinks and they were not even mixed well.The best parts of our stay were the rooms themselves. The decor is really quite nice and included Hawaiiana books and even a real ukulele that was able to be taken off the shelf to be played. We were surprised by the gift basket of goodies that as it turns out is complementary. There is a note inside that states that the basket is the one of many surprises we would find during our stay. I can't say that we found any other pleasant surprises during our stay, but the basket was nice and included 2 pairs of flip-flops, short bread cookies, local kine potato chips, candy and postcards. Our room had two King beds, which are certainly King size width but not length. My husband is 6'4" and his feet dangled off the edge when he laid on the bed which they do not on a regular queen size bed at home. The bathroom was really nice including a rather luxurious shower enclosure. We had a late flight out and were allowed to extend our check out time by one hour and they stored luggage for us several hours until our cab came to pick us up. We had a vehicle parked with the valet for several nights before bringing it to the port to ship. My husband discovered when he picked up his vehicle in the morning to take it to ship, that the valet broke the OBD-2 Connector and his onboard computer would not operate. Since it was very early when he picked up and he didn't have time to stop and argue due to needing to get to the port ASAP he wasn't able to address it with the valet staff. We figured the hotel would not take responsibility so we didn't even bother to mention it upon check out but certainly very disappointing and we will inoccur a cost to repair.All in all, we were very disappointed with this property and will not ever stay at this property again on future visits to the island.

Our friend was here from Kauai. So we decided to stay in Waikiki so we could enjoy the night life it had to offer. Chose Laylow for its hip and modern feel. We LOVED it. The staff was friendly and very helpful. They played really good music too. We will be definitely staying again in the future. This time bringing our fur baby.

We were expecting a boutique-y, charming hotel for our "laying low" weekend staycation. This is not to be found at the Lay Low. Upon entry, up the escalator to the lobby, we were slapped in the face with loud DJ party/dance club music. So loud that we had a difficult time speaking to the front desk attendant (who also commented that the music made her job challenging). The tiny lobby could not accommodate the crowd of people.While the room is cute with decorative items, it is not really functional and is very tiny. There are no hooks to hang towels anywhere, not in the bathroom, etc. The wallpaper is iconic and "cool", and the welcome basket with lay low slippers, etc is are nice touches.The small pool does not accommodate the crowd as well - kids splashing, families trying to cram into 1 of 2 pavilions, among couples looking for a luxury retreat. Service at the pool was minimal, at best. The location of the hotel is good for exploring Waikiki and nearby beaches. Our intention of our stay was to have a "stay-cation" and enjoy the hotel... this hotel does not fit that bill.

Low in perks for Marriott Elite members.Low standards of their so called executive rooms (do not be a fool and pay for it)Low service standards. Very nice staff but they lack the standard attention to service.The lack of care toward Marriott Elite members make this hotel a big looser in my book. They had the opportunity to stand out as a full-service Marriott in Hawaii that offers Gold and Platinum members some easy perks like a lounge and Breakfast. Yet it Is clear the cheap and bare bone options is what the management went for. They worked very hard to provide nothing with saying they provide everything. There is NO LOUNGE at this hotel do not be fooled like I did. I booked an executive room as it was the lowest class room open when I booked. I’m a Marriott gold, and normal perks are Upgrades, Lounge access and for hotels without a lounge full breakfast. This hotel is a scam! They say.. Oh yeah we have a lounge with “Drinks and Snacks” thru out the day and “continental breakfast”. Yet what I found was a table in the hallway with TAP water, a coffee machine, and 2 bins of mostly empty trail mix. Breakfast is the slap in the face that will wake you up. They have low end watered down OJ and donuts and some basic full fruit... I have seen more items at hotels at the front desk for all guest. The worst part is here is what is in the room description that I booked and paid for (Deluxe Room, Executive Level, Partial Ocean View and Mountain View, balcony) “Complimentary food: - Continental breakfast - midday snack Complimentary non-alcoholic beverages” again let me be clear as what this is in reality. Tap water, Trail mix, watered down OJ, coffee, donuts, fruit” In the hallway area they have a pull-out drink coolers that never had anything in it. I checked both the 15th and 16th floor. When asking the staff about this so called lounge, I was told “well sir, it is nice for free”. NOT FREE I booked a room that cost more with these so called perks. As for other perks as a gold.. NO upgrade or even a apology they could not upgrade me, NO Elite recognition, Nothing! At the bar as I was I talking to a Platinum guest who did get a $10 food voucher. Wow just shows this hotel is not trying to “deal” with Marriott Elite members. Fail! Now to the room. It is nice, modern but on the small side. Before they redid this place, it was a roach hotel. Not anymore. I would pick this place based on the room, but lack of so much makes the nice rooms last on my list. This hotel thinks they can survive based off being new and having nice rooms. Just not going to cut it in the sea of hotels in Waikiki. Room was clean, Bed was nice. Bathroom was small but nice, shower water pressure was not great. The wifi was SLOW and at times just did not work. The room style was cool and a good place to crash. Yet they lack of normal Marriott perks even for an Autograph collection hotel. One last thing there was a welcome basket in the room. A nice touch (I’m told this is for the so called Executive rooms) it was 2 sets of branded flip flops, 2 bottles of local soda, and some chips and cookies. But the thing I found a bit odd was two condoms at the bottom of the basket, I may be old school but this is odd for a High end Marriott branded hotel. I can not imagine how this could be awkward for parents who have kids running for the chips and find this.. Yes this hotel is new and my issues can not be put down as growing pains. It is a clearly calculated way to provide Marriott Elites the bare minimal with playing around the rules on what a hotel should provide.

I'm a huge fan of Marriott and was excited to try out the new LayLow in Honolulu. The website showed off the property and amenities and completely sold me on the experience. The reviews were also favorable. Unfortunately, the experience has fallen short... very short! I decided to upgrade to the "Executive level, Executive Suite, King, Sofa bed, Manoa Mountain view, Partial ocean view" with promises access to a Club Level experience. The website says: "Special Benefits" including:Complimentary food:- Continental breakfast- midday snack- Complimentary non-alcoholic beveragesThe complimentary food is a completely false representation. Continental breakfast this morning from 7-9am was "Lilikoi cronuts" and nothing more. At 715am there was no more orange juice, only water and coffee. Complimentary non-alcoholic beverages is literally water and coffee. There are two refrigerated drawers that have not been filled with any bottled water or beverages since we arrived. We've made it a point to check frequently throughout the day.On a positive note, the rooms are lovely! Spacious, well designed, beautiful decor. We did enjoy our welcome basket. That was the big plus of our stay but still not enough to make up for an "Executive Level" with disappointing 24/7 snacks and drinks. The other weird thing is that there is no ice available anywhere on the floor. We went in search of ice all over the floor then had to call down to the front desk. They are always happy to deliver things to us but that would've been nice to know upon check-in.Last rant- when we drove in, there was no one at the valet stand and no signage to indicate it was a valet stand. So we drove around the hotel 2x until we finally found our valet gentleman to help us. BTW-he was very nice.

We had two rooms with two king size beds in each room for our family. Very comfortable room only thing lacking was a tea/coffee kettle in room. When I called to ask if they had a kettle I could use to make my tea they said no. However, they did send someone to bring me two takeaway cups with lids filled with hot water. I was able to make a cup of tea and appreciate it. Bed very comfortable. Location was very good to shops/ beach and restaurants. AC worked well. Paid parking $35 a night for our rental. Also had a welcome basket with flip flops and local food that we enjoyed. Would recommend.

I had two reservations that I was choosing from, between Pacific Beach hotel and Laylow. I ended up choosing Laylow even though they were pricier because Pacific Beach was still under construction and I didn't want to hear construction noise. Laylow is a small hotel. They only have two people checking guest in. The check in process went smooth, but I noticed the person checking in next to me got a lot more information about the hotel. In terms of activities happening and where everything was. I just got my key cards handed to me. The rooms were nice. I liked that there were two king beds, but there is no other space for a table. So if you are here for business there is no table to do your work. When we got to our room I could hear construction going on for the building next to the hotel. Remember I chose this hotel because it was done remodeling with no construction. I called down to the front desk to ask if this would be going on all day and early morning. They assured me that it would not. So I decided to deal with it since we would be out. But early morning around 4am I could hear trucks back up all morning and then by 6;30am the construction started. I called the front desk later in the morning when I was about to head out about the noise. They said they could switch my room and to gather all my luggage in one spot for the bell hopper. I headed out for the day and by the time I got back that evening I got keys to my new room.They switched my room to the other side of the hotel away from the construction with a view of the pool on the 7th floor. Well on the weekends they have a DJ for the Hideout bar area near the front desk blasting music. I called down to the front desk Kim answered, I asked how long this music would go on til. She said midnight. With no apologies or anything. So I'm thinking fine I'll put on my ear plugs, but nope I could hear the music THROUGH my EAR PLUGS! That tells you how loud the music was. I had a early morning of activities. I called back down a couple of times and no on answered. I finally made one more call and the manager answered the phone. Kim must of known it was me and either didn't pick up or waited for the manager to pick up. If you call down at night its always the same person that picks up. That's how small they are. So the manager apologizes and says they'll have them turn the music down. That doesn't help at all. I call again and told her it didn't help and I could hear the music through my ear plugs. I also tell her I don't want to pack up and change rooms again as I'm only there for 4 nights. I didn't want to unpack and repack again. She said if the noise was still unbearable then to call back, but I didn't see what calling back would do as I really didn't want to change rooms again. That's not what I went on vacation to do. On top of all that in the new room there was a wad of dirty hair stuck on the wall of the shower. Which was gross!! I didn't get much sleep at all during my stay, as the first night there was the early construction in the first room, 2nd through 4th night I heard the blasting music every night! Which made it very tiring for the activities I had each day. This was not a relaxing vacation at all. Also they have no ice machines, or coffee machines in the rooms. So every time you want ice you have to call to get it. Nor was there paper and note pad in the rooms like majority of the hotels you stay at. So you have to call for every thing which means you have to tip for every thing there. Which isn't a problem, but for ice?Overall, I was very disappointed with my stay. Had I known all this I would not have booked with this hotel. I was unable to get any rest and paid more to stay here.

Aloha mai kakou! To the LayLow Team and anyone who may happen upon this review, I hope this finds you helpful. The LayLow Waikiki is my absolute new/new fave hotel in Waikiki. I was born and raised in Hawaii, on Oahu. As a local, staying in Waikiki can sometimes be such a hassle. It's hard because you want to have a vacation but can't afford to "travel" so for myself and many other locals, stay-cationing in Waikiki is the second best thing. The struggle presents itself when you want to enjoy your island home but among a sea of tourists. Many times hotels, public spaces can be so congested it's hard to enjoy. The LayLow presents a stunning solution to this dilemma. On to my personal review of staying at the LayLow, My friends and I made a weekend of staying at the LayLow because we had a special event to attend together. I had heard rave reviews of the hotel from my close friends and wanted to stay as well. Upon checking in and being helped by a staff who was nothing but absolutely lovely, I instantly fell in love with the hotel, and I hadn't even got to my room yet! The whole design aesthetic of the hotel is what charmed me straight off. A vintage 60's, old Waikiki Glam while still being very modern and accommodating in comparison to its competitors. Loved everything about the rooms. One of my best friends and I had shared a room, and the two king beds were absolute heaven to sleep on, the BEAUTIFUL WALLPAPER, the awesome gift basket you receive, luscious air conditioning, and a lovely bathroom. The wood tiling in the shower is stunning. Being a musician, particularly enjoyed that there is an actual good quality soprano ukulele in each room that guests can play with and get lessons. Another good friend of mine had a suite and SWEET LORD, the room is AMAZING. We wish we could live there. I did not want to leave. THE HIDEOUT is also another thing that amazed me about the LayLow. In Waikiki there are so many restaurants that tend to be too pricey, too fancy, and rely on gimmicks to sell food. The food here feels like old fashioned local comfort food with still feeling gourmet and elevated in taste and presentation. The bar, deck, and fire pit area which we were lucky enough to relax in is just another visually stunning part of the hotel. I do wish the pool was a bit bigger and deeper but it's still also very beautiful and the lounge chairs and beds by the pool are soooooo comfortable. Side note, we were lucky and was at the pool when the hotel gave FREE shave ice, it was no joke, THE BEST SHAVE ICE I've ever had. I hope I've included everything that I set out to talk about, bottom line I just want to build up and compliment the excellence of this hotel. Lastly the Valet staff is also very good! I HIGHLY RECOMMEND staying here, what I loved most was that, the location of the LayLow being where it is on Kuhio, and the layout of the hotel, you know you're in Waikiki but you can actually relax and be secluded from the crowds bustling just down the escalators. And if you do want to explore Waikiki, you're located in kind of a center of both Kuhio and Kalakaua Ave which makes getting around easy. Mahalo to the LayLow Ohana, I can't wait to come back with my friends and family.

I stayed here just one night during a recent business trip. The hotel is new and the design is awesome. You definitely feel like you are in Hawaii and not a typical Marriott, other than the good service. My room was large and nicely furnished. It included several interesting books as well as free amenities and snacks. The pool area is nice but relatively small. This is not a place to stay if you have young kids who like splashing around in a large pool. The hotel is more suited for couples and business travelers who want to know they are not on the mainland anymore. There is a great, and very popular, udon restaurant right across the street. The only downside of my stay was that the front desk neglected to text me when my room was ready. I will definitely stay here on my next trip.

As long time platinum Marriott customers, we have seen our fair share of every type of Marriott owned property. They did a great job with the renovation, top to bottom. Rooms are nice, public areas are very nice as well. Staff is friendly and professional. Downside is you're not on the beach, which we knew coming into this. The benefits for platinum members are just do not in any way live up to the standards of any other property we have stayed at. Terribly disappointing, really. The breakfast promised to platinum members is a complete joke.... pastries and beverages=not adequate. Worse, the "lounge" is literally a table in the hallway on a floor that all guests have access to. I explained my disappoint to the manager, and asked if there was anything she could do at all to help out with breakfasts since we'd have to be buying them, and was told that I got my $10 voucher (or 500 points) and there was nothing she could do. No willingness whatsoever to help us out. We visit Oahu several times a year and will be going back to the Waikiki Beach Marriott. We have six more nights here, and will be looking to move. Will post an update if necessary.

Excellent customer service, great location, cool vibe, and large rooms (2 king beds) helped make the stay excellent. From checkin to concierge, the staff was friendly and helpful. Greeting with fresh pineapple was a delight after flight to the islands as well as the gift basket in the room. The concierge (Expedia local travel expert) was extremely helpful and booked us a tour that was sold out when we tried to book it individually. Be sure to ask for beach towel use at the front desk.I was pleased they honored my late checkout request.Only issue is that Hideout bar often had special events which restricted use by hotel guests.

We decided to try this hotel based on the good reviews. It has been disappointing. Yesterday, we came back from the beach mid-afternoon to find that the room had not been serviced. I called the front desk and was told that they had until 5pm. At 5:30pm, we came back to a room that was still unmade. I called the front desk and she offered to send someone up. When I asked for a delay because we were getting ready for dinner, the agent told me she would check. There was no follow-up as to whether the room would be cleaned. When we got back, we still had dirty cups.While out, I called in to speak to the tour desk. When the agent there didn't answer, I was transferred back to the person who answered my call originally. She took my name and number and assured me that someone would get back to me. I am still waiting.Yesterday afternoon, the water in the shower was lukewarm. Last night it was cold. When I called, I was told that the engineer was working on it and I should try again in 30 minutes. I tried in 30 min and again in another 30 min. I tried again this morning and while warmer, the water was still cold. In the meantime, the water in the sink began coming out aerated and tasted like seltzer water. When I spoke to the front desk about the shower, I was given the same line as I was given last night. Now, there's no water from the sink at all.The staff seems young. Apparently they need more training.

I stayed here for 3 nights. This hotel features 1960's Hawaiian Modern mid-century design featuring nostalgic details, tropical greenery and modern comforts.Everyone who works at the hotel all seem to love their job and they all make you feel very welcomed. They were very accommodating. The staff at the front desk all work very hard to make sure you have everything you need for your stay. The rooms are amaaaazing! The best part about this hotel is that every room has a balcony and a breathtaking view of Waikiki. Some rooms face the beach, some face the mountains and some have a beautiful view of the world famous Diamond Head. My favorite view is of the mountains because in the morning you can watch the sunrise and the passing showers over Manoa Valley. The bathrooms are beautiful and have wooden tiling in the showers. The rooms are also equipped with USB docs, comfy robes, and a gift basket with all the things you need to experience the Hawai'i lifestyle. Downstairs on the lobby level you can enjoy a dip in the pool. It is designed for both relaxation and photographic appeal. It's literally an oasis. We joined them mid afternoon and had the BEST shaved ice on the island.Also on the lobby level is their restaurant, Hideout. Enjoy specialty cocktails or a relaxing lunch featuring Pacific Rim Cuisine. Everything on the menu is DELICIOUS! The Mainlander Burger is my favorite but don't miss out on their bowls, kalua pig egg rolls and fried rice skillets off of the breakfast menu.This hotel is perfect for everyone and I will most definitely be back to lay low and get away from it all!!!

Since opening in March, this hotel has become one of my all-time favorites. I've stayed here two times since they've opened and I LOVED both times. ROOMS: The rustic traditional old Hawaiian style furnishings and decorations give it a nostalgic feel all the while being sleek and modern. I love the colors. THE BEDS ARE SOO COMFY. FOOD: Hideout Restaurant/Bar has a nice ambient feel being an open air, and it's especially beautiful at night when the fire pits are lit. Food is amazing. STAFF: Everyone is so friendly and willing to help, especially the concierge and valet. They really make you feel at home and excellently assist in all your needs. Cool personal testimony- I was waiting for my car to pull up at around noon, and being that is was pretty hot, one of the valet attendants offer and say "it's pretty hot, you're welcomed to come stand over here if you'd like" pointing to where their desk is, supported by a big umbrella to keep the workers cool. Nothing big, but that small act of kindness left a huge impression.Stay here, you won't regret... you may end up lengthening your stay ;)

The idea was to get away for ten days, stay at a hotel that was centrally located, not too big, and that looked interesting. I booked this hotel as part of a Marriott vacation package. Overall, our experience was very good.On a scale of 1-5, I would give the hotel staff a 6. From the front desk staff to the concierges to the restaurant waiters to the hotel maids, they were all friendly, helpful, professional, very customer service-oriented. The hotel was recently renovated and beautifully decorated. The location was perfect, as was the size of the hotel.Two categories of things prevent a 5-star rating. First, the Marriot vacation package said we would have a "view." The balcony of our room looked straight into a parking garage. That doesn't fit my definition of a "view." Second, there were technical/technological problems that may relate to the recent renovation; they need to be resolved. We could not get HBO on our television and we had problems getting our cellphones to work in the room--these all seemed to relate to problems with the wifi service the hotel had gotten from an outside vendor. The other technical issues related to the elevators. The key card for the room also was to be used in the elevator to gain access to our floor. Frequently it did not work. On our last morning there, both elevators stopped working altogether. Fortunately, they were back in service by the time we had to take our suitcases down and check out.Besides the good experience at the hotel, we went on numerous tours that were great. The Circle tour of Oahu was not great due to the overbearing guide. Probably the most fun and interesting tour we took was a walking tour one evening with a company called Mysteries of Hawaii owned by Lopaka Kapanui. The most calming dining experience we had was a formal afternoon tea on the veranda overlooking the ocean at a wonderful hotel called the Moana Surfrider.All in all, a lovely vacation.

I've heard lots of great things about The Laylow, so when I decided to get a hotel in Waikiki on the weekend of my two-day business conference, this was the chance I was able to see what the fuss was about.The staff all over the hotel was amazing. Friendly valet guys.... welcoming front desk... cheerful housekeeping staff.... and the managers always seemed to be walking around the hotel and restaurant asking if we were enjoying ourselves and if we needed anything. Rooms were clean... comfy beds.... I got the suite to get the full experience.... and because I saw that they were pet-friendly, I brought my dog with me... they had a doggie bed and bowls waiting for us when we got in the room. My dog didn't even want to sleep by me because she loved how comfy her bed was. And when we'd walk in and out of the hotel, the staff would address my dog too. She had a BLAST!Also... that welcome gift basket in the room with the slippers, and snacks?! You better believe I ate and drank everything in there! And I wore my slippers with pride! Fun!Don't get me started with the Hideout restaurant! Because I was there from Friday through Tuesday, I was able to experience their DJs on Friday and Saturday AND the live music (they have live music Sunday-Thursday). It was a great way to wind down when I'd get back to the hotel.The food at the restaurant was tasty and fresh.... best burgers and poke tacos you'll ever eat! It's so hard not to want to come and hang at least once a month ... it's a great experience. You HAVE to check it out for yourself!

I stayed here for two nights over the weekend and was not ready to leave at all. I'm going to bullet point this review to try and keep it concise:-Staff: Everyone on staff that I encountered was incredibly friendly, I mean everyone; Valet, front desk, housekeeping, servers and managers at the Hideout restaurant, everyone. The front desk was especially helpful in helping track down a suit that I had misplaced on my last day.-The room: Fresh, cheerful, and very comfortable. I booked a junior suite with a king bed, and the decor was fun, very trendy & retro. There was a cute gift basket with local treats and two pairs of slippers (flip flops) on the surfboard shaped coffee table. I was delighted to see a small collection of popular books on Hawaiian culture & history and there was also a tenor ukulele that I enjoyed playing in my room. There was also a cute little office nook tucked away behind the TV. I was happy to find USB docs on both sides of the very comfortable bed for device charging.-Pool: The pool is a wading/hangout style pool (only gets 3 feet deep) with nifty little one piece lounge chair-things that are submerged about 6 inches on one side of the pool which I found fun for pretending to be in a luxury vacation photo shoot. There are also two cabanas opposite the pool entrance, a bunch of two-person day beds and free shaved-ice near the pool in the lobby (not sure if this was a Sunday thing or an everyday thing?)-Hideout restaurant: Very cool semi-covered roof-top restaurant & bar, two firepits,and great pacific fusion food. Organic beef burgers and creative poke bowls were a favorite.-Location: The hotel isn't on the "main" Waikiki road which was great because you don't get the same pedestrian and vehicle traffic congestion. The new International marketplace is right next door and there are lots of neat little local restaurants in close walking distance.To summarize, I had an exceptional stay and am definitely planning on returning for another staycation as soon as I can. I very highly recommend the Lawlow!

The Laylow Waikīkī is the perfect getaway for visitors and locals alike, including extraordinary service with genuine aloha and an Instagram-perfect mid century modern aesthetic. Thoughtful details at every turn including the signature wallpaper which matches straws, slippers and poolside towels, welcome baskets in our room, complimentary shave ice by the pool and excellent food at Hideout. The Laylow is a true hidden gem in Waikīkī...we are already planning our return!

The hotel was fabulous. All around excellence. Great decor and ambience. Would return again and recommend the hotel to others. Want to thank Patricia Guterres for making the arrangements for our family accommodations and party at the Hideout restaurant.

Stayed here a couple nights - very impressed by the decor (mid century modern, think Brady Bunch Hawaii episode). Service is exceptionally good, staff members going out of their way to please. Beds are still firm/comfortable, but this is a new property. Pool and exercise room are small but it works.HOWEVER, as a Marriott elite member, this property is a disappointment when it comes to elite benefits. As noted earlier, there is no serious breakfast benefit that Marriott Gold/Platinum members would normally get. Instead, what they have "negotiated" (per the front desk) is a Keurig coffee machine and one pastry type that varies by the day. There isn't an executive lounge, despite the hotel selling "Executive Level" rooms! What a joke. There is a nice restaurant on site and one would typically expect a daily breakfast voucher in lieu of the lounge breakfast.. well, guess what - no breakfast coupon either. Forget about complimentary room upgrades for elite members - not offered. Might have to beg the front desk for this one. If you are here on business, the rooms have a tiny desk in each room. It's not really a desk where you can work on. The hotel lists a business kiosk in the lobby, according to their materials.. surprise -- none exists. Per the front desk, there is a tablet available for use (I cannot imagine how this helps anyone). Best of all (insert sarcasm here), there is a Destination Amenity fee of $25 per day.Notice how it's not called a Resort Fee, probably because it's not a resort (not on the beach!). What amenities does one receive due to the fee? Hmm.. I wonder. In conclusion, this property is great if you got lucky with your Priceline bid or if you want nice sized hotel rooms in a great location (International Marketplace is next door!). Marriott elites, biz travelers - look elsewhere to get your money's worth.

I was only in Waikiki for a one night stay, so my review is based on an extremely short list. Pulling up, I was greeted by a friendly valet attendant whom I told I was checking in but planned to leave once I dropped my bags. He said he would keep the car ready. I was directed to an escalator (there's an elevator too) with directions to the front desk. Walking up to the front desk I was greeted by name (nice touch by the valet) and promptly checked-in. As a platinum Rewards Member, I was given a nice little upgrade to a junior suite. This was much appreciated even if traveling solo and was also told there would be a welcome basket with some complimentary items (they might do this for everyone). The room was a nice size with a sitting area and probably the size of two normal rooms. It was on a lower floor so my view was of a parking garage, but it wasn't a big deal given my short stay and the free upgrade. Overall, everyone on the staff was very friendly and accommodating.
